Description: This is a buff coloured clay oil lamp of circular shape with a funnel shaped open tube leading up in the centre. There is a circular rim at the top of an edge, and there is an oval hole in one side. The underside has an incised circular ring. The surface is undecorated. Wheel-made lamp with hole in middle. Buff fabric with quartz and grey inclusions.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by City Art Gallery and Museum, Bristol. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Parallels from Athens (Howland 1958, see types 9 and 11). Parallels from Rhodes (one from a grave, another from domestic structure), Megara Hyblaea and Chios, from contexts dated to between 625BC and 570BC, though Bailey dates this form to 600BC - 575BC (Bailey 1975, 94, Q147). Parallels in the British Museum from Ephesus (British Museum GR 1971,1224.9) and parallels from Naukratis (British Museum GR 1886,0401.1336; Boston MFA 86.899; 88.906; Fitzwilliam, Cambridge GR.57.1899; Bristol Museum H846). Howland, R.H. 1958. The Athenian Agora, IV, Greek lamps and their survivals. Princeton.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (KC.12) (Phase 1)
